newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada's Alberta backs away from tax cuts.
newsitem.headline: Canada's Alberta backs away from tax cuts.

text.p: Residents and firms in Canada's western province of Alberta can put to rest any hope of a tax cut in the coming fiscal year, Alberta Treasurer Jim Dinning said on Sunday.
"If you want taxes reduced, you'd better be able to afford that loss of tax revenue forever," Dinning said in a report filed by the Canadian Press.
The Alberta government in June cancelled plans for C$295 million in personal income tax cuts to items such as provincial surtaxes.
It announced plans to cut taxes in February.
High oil prices and dropping interest rates should leave Alberta with a C$1.7 billion surplus in 1996/97.
Alberta decided to scrap plans for the tax cut until it reduced its debt more and is sure future economic downturns will not leave it missing the tax revenue, Dinning said.
"Taxation can't be like a Jolly Jumper -- down and then up again," he said.
"Taxes should only go one way -- down."
The windfall from oil and gas royalties in higher than expected energy prices won't last forever and Alberta wants every extra cent to pay down the debt faster, he said.
"You can't count on $25 (U.S.)-a-barrel forever," Dinning said.
